heart size is moderately enlarged, unchanged. the lungs demonstrate basilar atelectasis. there is no evidence of effusion, airspace disease or pneumothorax. an aicd with two metallic leads overlying the right atrium and right ventricle are noted. impression: no acute cardiopulmonary process. ekg : baseline artifact. sinus rhythm with ventricular premature beats. p-r interval prolongation. intraventricular conduction delay. consider inferior myocardial infarction. since the previous tracing of the rate has increased. ventricular premature beats are more frequent. q-t interval is shorter. ekg : no qt prolongation. brief hospital course: 67 year old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy (ef <20%) s/p mi and icd with subsequent vt s/p ablation, h/o amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis presenting with icd discharges. . vt s/p icd discharge: patient had been ablated for vt in the past. however, his icd was interrogated by ep and showed 9 episodes of fast vt with cl 300-320 msec with similar morphology, some of which responded to atp while others required shock. he likely has scar mediated vt, likely from an inferior origin. there were no signs or symptoms suggestive of an acute ischemic trigger, and patient was continued on his home meds of asa, statin, beta blocker, and ace-i. tfts and electrolytes were within

normal limits. the icd setting was changed from burst to a more agressive sequence, and his sotalol was increased from 120 mg to 160 mg ; amiodarone was discontinued as he had a h/o of amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis. for the rest of his hospital course, pt remained asymptomatic with several short runs of nsvt on telemetry but no more significant arrhythmias. on discharge, pt was stable on sotalol with no need for amiodarone or ablation at this point; ekg with no qt prolongation. he will follow up with doctor . . amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis: endocrine was consulted and determined that patient's history was most consistent with type ii ait in light of his small nonnodular thyroid as well as absence of previous thyroid disease and antithyroid antibodies. his tfts were nl during this admission, and it was determined that it would be safe to restart the amiodarone if needed since the risk of ait recurrence is approximately 10%. at this time, the patient is not a candidate for thyroid ablation as he received a large iodine load from the initial amiodarone bolus. however, if amiodarone is restarted in the future, prophylactic thyroid ablation with radioiodine should be considered. pt will follow up with doctor . medications on admission: sotalol 120 mg aspirin 325 mg daily atorvastatin 40 mg daily metoprolol succinate 150 mg daily ramipril 10 mg daily amlodipine 5 mg daily esomeprazole 40 mg zantac 150 mg prn (averages 2x/week) discharge medications: omeprazole 20 mg capsule, delayed release(e.c.) sig: one (1) capsule, delayed release(e.c.) po bid (2 times a day). atorvastatin 40 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po daily (daily). aspirin 325 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po daily (daily). ramipril 5 mg capsule sig: two (2) capsule po daily (daily). amlodipine 5 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po daily (daily). toprol xl 50 mg tablet sustained release 24 hr sig: three (3) tablet sustained release

24 hr po once a day. sotalol 160 mg tablet sig: one (1) tablet po twice a day. disp:*60 tablet(s)* refills:*2* discharge disposition: home discharge diagnosis: primary: ventricular tachycardia . secondary: h/o amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis cad s/p mi x 3 chronic systolic heart failure (ef 20%) hyperlipidemia s/p icd placement & vt ablation discharge condition: asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable for discharge with appropriate follow-up. discharge instructions: you were admitted to after being shocked by your implanted defibrillator. the device revealed that you have had multiple episodes of ventricular tachycardia. your icd settings were adjusted, and your sotalol dose was increased with good control of your rhythm subsequently. the following change were made to your medications: sotalol increased to 160 mg two times a day please take all medications as prescribed. for control of your congestive heart failure, please weigh also adhere to 2 gm sodium diet. if you experience any chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, dizzyness, more icd discharges, or any other concerning symptoms, please call 911 or come to the er. followup instructions: cardiology provider: , md phone: appointment date/time: 4:00pm endocrinology provider: , md phone: appointment date/time: 11:00am primary care doctor: , md please call to schedule an appointment to be seen within the next 3 weeks.
